stem: A client who had an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the left tibia 2 days ago reports increasing throbbing pain in the left leg that is unrelieved by opioid pain medication. Which of the following actions is the nurse's priority?

rationale.correct: Compartment syndrome is a limb-threatening condition caused by increased pressure within a confined space, leading to decreased blood flow and nerve damage. The priority is to immediately assess the 6 P's (Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis, and Pressure) to evaluate for compartment syndrome. Notifying the surgeon promptly is crucial for potential fasciotomy to relieve the pressure. Elevating the extremity at heart level can help reduce edema but is secondary to immediate assessment. Administering more pain medication will not address the underlying cause and may mask worsening symptoms.
rationale.incorrect: Administering another dose of pain medication will not address the underlying problem of compartment syndrome. Elevating the leg above the heart can reduce arterial pressure, potentially worsening ischemia. Assessing pulses distal to the injury is an important component of assessing compartment syndrome, but it is not the immediate priority. The priority is a comprehensive assessment of all 6 P's.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition of compartment syndrome is crucial to prevent permanent damage.
Pain that is out of proportion to the injury and unrelieved by analgesics is a hallmark sign of compartment syndrome.
Prompt surgical intervention (fasciotomy) may be necessary to relieve pressure in compartment syndrome.

questionTrap.trap: Students often focus on pain management first without recognizing the potential for a limb-threatening complication like compartment syndrome.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the underlying cause of the pain and potential complications, especially in post-operative orthopedic patients. Prioritize assessment for serious complications before solely addressing pain.

mnemonic.title: 6 P's of Compartment Syndrome
mnemonic.expansion: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pressure

reviewUnits.title: Compartment Syndrome
reviewUnits.content: Compartment syndrome is a condition caused by increased pressure within a confined space, typically in the extremities, leading to decreased blood flow and nerve damage. Early recognition and intervention are essential to prevent permanent disability. Key signs and symptoms include severe pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, paralysis, and increased pressure in the affected compartment.

itemContext.sbar: 0700: Nurse Smith reporting on Jane Doe, post-op day 2 ORIF left tibia. 62-year-old female admitted for open reduction internal fixation of left tibia fracture. 0800: Patient reports throbbing pain in left leg rated 8/10, unrelieved by morphine 4mg IV given at 0600. 0815: Pedal pulse present but diminished in left foot compared to right. Capillary refill > 3 seconds in left toes. Toes cool to touch. 0830: Patient reports increasing numbness in left foot. Dressing clean, dry, and intact. No active bleeding noted. Orders include morphine 4mg IV q2 hours PRN pain, neurovascular checks q4 hours. Concerns for potential compartment syndrome given pain level and neurovascular changes. Requesting further evaluation. VS stable: BP 130/80, HR 92, RR 18, SpO2 98% on room air.

options.text: Assess the client's pain, pallor, pulses, paresthesia, paralysis, and pressure of the affected extremity.
Administer another dose of opioid pain medication as prescribed.
Elevate the client's left leg above the level of the heart.
